title: A Phase 1b, Multicenter, Double-Blind, Randomized, Placebo-Controlled, Sequential Dose Study of the Safety and Tolerability of ASP0777 in Subjects With Alzheimer's Disease on Donepezil
description_brief: This study is intended to determine the safety and tolerability of ASP0777 in subjects with Alzheimer's Disease (AD) taking a stable dose of donepezil.
drug: ASP0777 (ASP-0777) — investigational small-molecule NMDA receptor antagonist (Astellas).
explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests ASP0777 added to stable donepezil to determine safety/tolerability in AD, which implies a symptomatic treatment approach rather than a diagnostic or purely biomarker study. The clinical record lists ASP0777 as an oral investigational drug in a Phase 1b randomized, placebo‑controlled safety study. citeturn2search1turn2search0

Act: Public sources identify ASP0777 (ASP-0777) as an NMDA‑receptor antagonist and list the Astellas Phase 1b study NCT01406145 (60 subjects) evaluating safety/tolerability; the trial documentation also excludes subjects with a history of intolerance to memantine (another NMDA antagonist), supporting that ASP0777 is in the same mechanistic class. citeturn2search3turn2search1

Reflect: NMDA receptor antagonists (e.g., memantine) are small molecules used to modulate glutamatergic neurotransmission to improve cognition/symptoms in AD rather than directly targeting core AD pathology (amyloid/tau) — therefore ASP0777 is best classified as a cognitive enhancer (small‑molecule symptomatic therapy) rather than a disease‑targeting biologic or disease‑modifying small molecule. The trial title and design (safety/tolerability, short dosing up to 6 weeks as reported) are consistent with a symptomatic small‑molecule development program. Note: published clinical outcome data are limited in public registries; most sources emphasize safety/pharmacokinetics rather than disease‑modification claims. citeturn2search1turn2search3turn3search4

Summary conclusion: Category = "cognitive enhancer" because ASP0777 is a small‑molecule NMDA receptor antagonist being developed as a symptomatic (cognitive) therapy in AD; not classified as a disease‑targeted biologic or disease‑modifying small molecule based on available information. citeturn2search3turn2search1
explanation_agent: Reason: The investigational drug ASP0777 is described in sponsor/registry records as an oral small‑molecule NMDA (N‑methyl‑D‑aspartate) receptor antagonist given to subjects with AD on donepezil, i.e., it modulates a neurotransmitter receptor (glutamatergic NMDA) to produce symptomatic/cognitive effects rather than directly targeting amyloid, tau, or other disease‑modifying pathways. citeturn0search2turn0search5

Act: Extracted facts from public records — ASP0777 (ASP‑0777) is listed as an NMDA‑receptor antagonist and the study is a Phase 1b randomized, placebo‑controlled safety/tolerability trial in AD patients on stable donepezil (N=60 as reported). Exclusion criteria in trial listings also note intolerance/use-of‑memantine considerations, supporting its membership in the NMDA antagonist class. citeturn0search5turn0search8turn1search2

Reflect: NMDA receptors are a neurotransmitter receptor class (glutamate receptors). Under the CADRO taxonomy the most specific match for a trial whose mechanism is NMDA receptor antagonism is D) Neurotransmitter Receptors (symptomatic/cognitive‑enhancer class). There is no indication this agent was tested primarily as an anti‑amyloid, anti‑tau, anti‑inflammatory, or multi‑target disease‑modifying therapy in the provided description and registry records, so D is the appropriate CADRO category. citeturn0search2turn0search5
